## 사건 정보

**사건명**: Paul E. Timmons, Georgia P. Timmons v. William S. Campbell, Arthur Lee Pittard, Sheriff of Sussex County, Delema S. Hauger
**판결일**: 1955-01-24
**법원**: New York Court of Chancery
**관할**: New York, NY

**판사**: Seitz

## 변호인

Houston Wilson, Georgetown, for plaintiffs., James M. Tunnell, Sr. (of Tunnell & Tunnell), Georgetown, for defendant, William S. Campbell., Lawrence C. Elliott, Georgetown, for defendant, Delema S. Hauger., Defendant, Arthur Lee Pittard, sheriff, did not appear.

## 인용

- 35 Del. Ch. 68

## 판결문 요약


Seitz, Chancellor:
Plaintiffs seek to enjoin the enforcement of a Superior Court judgment of ejectment obtained against them by the defendant William S. Campbell. Alternatively, they seek to recapture from the defendant Hauger, who sold them the property, the purchase price with interest and expenses, and they seek to recover from the defendant, Campbell, the value of improvements made on the property and taxes paid, with interest.
*69They seek to enjoin Campbell on the ground of equitable estoppel while they seek the recapture of the value of improvements, etc., on the ground of their good faith and Campbell’s silence under circumstances tantamount to fraud. They seek to recapture the purchase price from the seller on the ground of fraud and misrepresentation.
On April 19, 1898, one Prettyman D. Smith (called the “testator”) died leaving a will dated January 21, 1898. By his will he devised his 109 acre farm in Nanticoke Hundred, Sussex County to his son, William M. Smith (called “William” or “life tenant”) for life and if his son “should die without lawful issue at the time of his death” then the farm was to go in fee to the defendant Campbell. He was the son of the testator’s daughter. There is no specific language of devise in the event William M. Smith died with lawful issue surviving. Since the point is not here raised, I infer that all parties agree that the language created an implied remainder in such issue. I proceed on that premise.
